text: At the bottom of a 1970s avocado bath, a bathplug chain drifts from side to side in the soapy water.

Every great athlete is born with a natural talent. Arnold Palmer, Jimmy Connors, Muhammad Ali, the illustrious Brazilian Pele... A boy's hand appears holding a waterproof plastic watch. seconds tick by as bubbles begin to stream upwards.
Every sporting legend you can mention — naturally gifted from birth. Ten-year-old Eddie Edwards bursts to the surface, purple faced and gasping for air. EDDIE (VO) (CONT’D) And I was no exception.
Little Eddie, hair still wet, carries his Gola kitbag to front door. He is a stocky kid with a determined jaw.
A week after my tenth birthday I equalled the Cheltenham Junior Swimming League record for holding my breath underwater. He stands on tiptoes, straining for the lock.

That meant I was ready to compete at the highest level. A woman in a nightgown appears — Eddie’s mother JANETTE. She's a large, jolly woman in a muumuu and brown tinted glasses, equal parts warmth and anxiety.
And where d'you think you're going, young man?

Rome. I'm going to hold my breath in the Olympics and win a gold medal. She regards him thoughtfully, then goes and rummages in t hall closet. Among the coats and umbrellas is a pair of National Healt KNEE CALIPERS. Eddie looks at them darkly until she emerges holding out empty Jaffa Cakes biscuit tin.
Well, you’d better take this for your medals then, hadn't you. Eddie tucks the tin under his arm, relieved. “Good thinki
And make sure you pack your hankie.
Eddie walks along the damp pavement. It’s a neglected wor class neighborhood, all stray dogs and misspelled graffit
I soon found out there wasn't an Olympic event for holding your breath. He studies the time-table at a bus stop.
And there wasn't a bus to Rome from the end of our street. (rain drizzles down) And Mum was absolutely right. He wipes a sleeve over his runny nose.
I should have packed my hankie.
Eddie toys with a consoling cup of cocoa, poring over his treasured 1972 Olympics photo album — Moments of Glory.
But I didn't care. I knew I was going to be a part of it someday. He studies the Kodachrome images enrapt — Jesse Owens, Ol Korbut, Mark Spitz — triumphant medal winners cheered and chaired aloft.
Alright, pet. Time for bed. She removes his cup, revealing Eddie's handiwork: five chocolate rings on the plastic tablecloth — the Olympic l
The first step was finding the right sport.
Eddie swings a battered old cricket bat at an incoming ba and misses completely.
Something that played to my strengths. He swings again with the same result. And again. And agai long into the night.
I knew there'd be technical difficulties, and a fair bit of soul-searching. Eddie trudges home, dragging his kitbag behind him.
Every great sportsman has to confront his demons eventually. Eddie walks smack bang into a lamp post.

But it helps if you can see them first.  4. Eddie squints through an ancient eye test machine at a ch of letters — all wildly blurred. Thick lenses are dropped in front of his eyes, snapping t letters in focus.
Mum was a big fan of my new incarnation. Eddie shows off his new spectacles — National Health jam- lenses with thick black frames.
Very smart.
Dad too, I think. Eddie’s Dad, TERRY, is a no-nonsense ruddy-faced builder. gives the glasses a wiggle.
"My name is Michael Caine."
The playground was less convinced.
Oi Four-eyes!/Goggle-eyed git! A dozen kids make “goggle” faces through the threadbare cricket netting. Eddie gives them a V-sign. Resumes his stance at the wicket.
It makes a big difference being able to see properly. He swings at the incoming ball and just like before, miss completely — taking this one right in the face.
You get a much clearer perspective on the best way to fulfill your sporting potential.
Eddie drops his broken glasses into the biscuit tin.

Like making sure you pick the right size ball for your physical type. Eddie in ill-fitting shirt and shorts, chases a bobbling rugby ball, trying to scoop it up without success until t opposing team flattens him. INT. EDDIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Another pair of broken glasses drops into the tin.
And choosing the best terrain for your endurance capabilities.
A starting pistol sends Eddie and his classmates into the freezing water. They all emerge and swim off except f you know who.
Let’s just say it was a process of trial and error.
We move down Eddie’s effortfully handwritten list of spor cricket, football, swimming, hurdles, boxing... All cross out except for the last one — cycling.

Eddie peddles furiously on his trusty Raleigh Chopper — picking up speed towards a home-made jumping ramp. The local kids watch as he flies into the air — so high t he clears the long line of milk crates. He lands safely with a triumphant WHOOP only to discover he hasn’t left enough room to stop.
Shhhhhhhhhhhiiii- He SLAMS into a neighbor’s wall and FLIPS over the hedge a CRASH of glass and a sickening THUD.
It was not what you’d call a textbook landing, but I couldn’t have been happier. The local kids wince as they find Eddie writhing amid the remains of a smashed green house.
I was on my way. Part of the big show, admired and appreciated for who I was. Eddie is helped to his feet, badly cut and covered with broken plants.
Fucking maniac!
And then came the bombshell. Eddie lies on his bed reading Moments of Glory, like he d every night. A boy alone under his Evel Knievel poster.
Eddie! Get down here now!
Janette and Terry sit at the Formica table, bewildered an exasperated at this crazy son of theirs covered in scratc and cuts.
Enough’s enough. You're spending your holidays with me down at the site. It’s time you learn the plastering trade. Eddie digests this like a death sentence, knee bouncing u and down.
What about my Olympic preparations? Terry says nothing. Just picks off some debris from Eddie sweater. Eddie looks to Mum. But she has to agree with Da
You never know, pet, you might like it.
Eddie sits with his bike, gazing out over the lights of Cheltenham below.
So that was the sporting career of Eddie Edwards. Down below him is a dirty noisy building site — his futur

Eleven different sports and nothing to show for it except twelve pairs of broken glasses. (I sat on my sixth pair in the library.) He scratches his knees absently as his defeated face slip into darkness. The crushing despair that only a 10-year-b can feel. We hold. Long enough to feel this could be the end of our story... and it probably would be except for the blaze of white light that suddenly illuminates the sky. Eddie sits up annoyed, but then increasingly intrigued.
He pedals back down the hill as fast as his wobbly wheel allow. Reaches a wire fence with a big sign: "ENGLAND'S FIRST DRY SKI SLOPE —

He dumps his bike to get a closer look: "In conjunction w the British Olympic Ski Association." His gaze drops to the corner of the sign. There it is. Th magic symbol of the Olympics — five interlocking rings.
Eddie clambers over the wire fence and scrambles up the d slope, all pain forgotten as he steps into the glaring li

Bloody ada. He is standing at the top of a HUGE floodlit ski slope. He steps out onto the plastic surface and feels the sprin bristles under his feet. He’s awe-struck, like he’s stepp out for the first time onto the moon. His battered urchin features tremble with emotion as he’s swallowed up by the heavenly glare of the floodlights...

The rousing theme tune from BBC’s Ski Sunday. Out of the whiteness comes an adult SKIER zig-zagging down a slalom course towards a finish line, snow spraying in his wake. A title card reads: "12 years later." A crowd leaps to its feet, deafeningly loud.

.+. This is amazing! This is sensational! Edwards is carving up the Calgary hillside like a Sunday roast. RON PICKERING, the BBC’s tubby, excitable voice of skiing grabs his microphone as the skier crosses the finish line RON PICKERING (CONT’D) Oh my word! He’s only gone and done it. The crowd swarms forward as ADULT EDDIE takes off his goggles. He’s in his 20s with a tan and cool bouffant hai RON PICKERING (CONT’D) Get out the champagne because Great Britain has just taken its first ever gold in the men’s downhill. And this is the man responsible, “Fast” Eddie Edwards. The crowd lifts up Eddie with a cheer.  RON PICKERING (CONT’D) The plasterer’s son from Cheltenham — now turned alpine champion and world-class — WOMAN’S VOICE Oh for gawd's sake. Get a wiggle on. Ron Pickering looks up confused. So does the crowd. Eddie drops backwards to the ground. WOMAN'S VOICE (CONT’D) Come on. Pick a lane.

A horn HONKS and Eddie snaps to. He is in the front seat being driven along by his MOTHER. A Charles and Di air- freshener swings from the rearview mirror. In reality, Eddie is a stocky bloke in his twenties with large jaw, no tan and gingery close cropped hair. His jam spectacles are held together by a Band-Aid.
Here we go, pet. His mother turns off past a sign: "British Men's Downhill Trials."

The crowd is modest but well-heeled. Barbour jackets, cravats, Hermés headscarves. They applaud politely as a skier crosses the finish line. Over in the sponsors’ enclosure, a throng of suited businessmen pay slightly more attention to the canapés an free champagne. A title card reads: "England, September 1986."
The Edwards family van noses its way between Range Rovers Jaguars to find a parking spot.  10.
Janette and Eddie share a final glance. This is his big moment, even though they’re both trying to act like it is

Knock ‘em dead. He grabs his skis and races off to the check-in, obliviou he clips a wing mirror. She watches him go, and we see th true depth of her anxiety at having a daredevil like Eddi for a child. She takes out her wool and needles. Starts to knit. Alone the dirty cement covered van.

The room is full of Olympic class skiers, which means a hubbub of blokey posh accents. They’re in no hurry to acknowledge Eddie as he breezes in. He covers up his discomfort by humming to himself until finally, he finds a spare coat hook at the end.
Great Britain has languished for too long on past glories - in business and in sports.
The sponsors have gathered round a podium to hear DUSTIN TARGET’s address. He is the conscientious new broom head BOSA with immaculate green blazer and name tag to prove i
But just as you have entered a new era of business, so we have embarked on a new era of sports — and it’s one that requires a new kind of athlete.
Eddie shuffles forward, flapping his arms and making stra warm-up noises.
Edwards, E. Cheltenham Winter Sports Centre.  11. The STARTING OFFICIAL directs Eddie to the start gate; a glance at Eddie's shoddy equipment.
Target surveys the crowd to make sure his theme is resonating.
And just as the world of business looks to sporting champions for inspiration, so we in turn can now look to you — our distinguished sponsors — for ways to make our athletes more competitive.

You are not just successful competitors. You’re brand leaders — the best in your field. And you deserve the best in return. Eddie wipes the steam off his goggles and snaps them into place. They're pink.
Target leans forward, savoring his crowd-pleasing big fin
Ladies and gentlemen, today you’re going to see just that. The KLAXON rudely cuts the applause short.

Eddie smashes down the plastic slope. He barely follows t "line," which shows his best quality is suicidal bravery. much style, plenty of guts. One by one, the sponsors turn to watch. Eddie takes the corners too fast and too tight, slamming slalom flags. He looks like he'll wipe out at any moment, amazingly he hangs on.  12. Target's face tightens at this careening blot on his landscape, flailing into the last two turns. Suddenly the flaw in Eddie’s all-out approach becomes apparent. He simply fails to make one of the turns. He flies off the course, right through the sponsors’ enclosure, and SMASHES into one of the hoardings. Silence. The drip of toppled ice buckets. The dismayed st of sponsors at the smashed billboard. "I bet he drinks Carling Black Label." Target turns to his Aide. Beckons him over. Now.
The Course Official escorts Eddie off the slope.
See that? I was pinging down the hill like a ferret. The Official can only watch as Eddie re-assembles his glasses, wired with excitement
Forty-five seconds at the halfway line. If I'd gone any faster I'd have taken off.
Er, you did. Eddie looks up. It’s Target’s Aide and he’s holding out Eddie’s gear and kitbag.
Hold a minute. I’ve still got a second run to do.
Not anymore. Eddie doesn’t understand. Until he follow’s the Aide’s glance. Locates the real reason for his expulsion - the distant hovering figure of Target.
The Aide escorts Eddie and his skis back to his van.  13.
This is outrageous.
It’s very simple. We've only got 18 months to prep the squad for Calgary. You’re just too raw.
But I’ve got run times as good as that bunch.
It's not just about speed. It's about finesse. Polish. Boys who can fit seamlessly into the squad.
Public school boys, you mean. The Aide doesn’t try to deny it. He hands Eddie his kit b Leaves him next to his van: “Edwards & Son, Quality Finis Get plastered with us!”
A pneumatic drill ROARS. Eddie is up to his elbows in muc “knocking up” a big tin of plaster on a busy renovation j DAD inspects the resulting plaster like a three star chef
Too thick.
“Too thick”? I’ve been going like a Kenwood mixer all morning. Terry fetches the water hose, unmoved.
Quality plastering’s no different from anything else. You want to get on, you gotta put in the graft.
“Quality plastering.” All I’m doing is mixing up mud. Terry hands Eddie the water hose.  14.
There’s no quality plaster without quality mud. Eddie kicks dried cement off his boots.
Yeah, well, I’m still stuck in it.
How many times I got to tell you? Do your City and Guilds and get qualified.

Eddie at work in the wet and the cold - lugging bricks, hauling cement, stirring plaster. Hating every minute eve though he never buckles. He gets his weekly pay envelope from the OFFICE GIRL and a pittance. He looks over to see his Dad getting yelled a the FOREMAN. Such is life on a building site.

The BRICKIES sit around at lunchtime reading the tabloids smoking roll-ups. They’re a hard-bitten lot. A couple eve swig beer. Eddie sits off to one side, munching on a banana and milk from a carton. His fingernails chipped with dried cement.

That's strange. They must have cropped you out. The Brickie holds out his tabloid to Eddie. On the sports pages is a photo of Target and the British Downhill squad heading off to St. Moritz. Eddie grabs the paper to see for himself. All the athlete their Olympic blazers. The final nail in the coffin. The Brickie starts humming the BBC "Ski Sunday" theme mus and miming the slalom.
Get stuffed.  15.
Hey, I wasn't the one telling everyone I was going to be on the team.

It’s not a team. It’s a squad. You don’t even know what you’re talking about. The other workmen join in the humming, drowning Eddie out even after he throws his banana skin at them. INT. EDDIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Eddie lies on his bed amid his Olympic shrine. Skiing posters, Olympic albums, photos of young Eddie accepting junior trophies, showing off his latest plaster cast; old Eddie teaching little kids how to ski. His Mother enters with some tea and Jaffa Cakes on a tray By his bedside is the newspaper story about the British Downhill Squad.
Come on, pet. It’s not the end of world.
No. It just feels like it. He rolls over onto his side, but there’s no escape. Even duvet cover has a Winter Olympic pattern — skiing, tobogganing, ski-jumping...

Eddie works away in the sunshine. Radio 1 in the backgrou He’s graduated from mixing to proper plastering now. Terry gives an approving nod then exits, past JULIE, the office girl who hands out the weekly paychecks.
Hello stranger.
Alright Julie. How’s it going? She comes up to Eddie with his envelope. They regard each other for a moment, quite comfortable together.  16.
So you're finally going for your diploma?
City and Guilds. Level one.
What about your downhill training? He gives an airy wave of his trowel.
Hanging out with a bunch of chinless wonders. Who needs it? Not him, that’s for sure.
If I wanted to be “polished,” I'd be a bloody doorknob, wouldn’t I. She waits. Lets him finish.
So you're free at the weekends then? She hands Eddie his pay envelope. Makes him tug it to get it free.

Eddie inspects his smartest ‘date’ outfit in the mirror — dark shellsuit. It’s fair to say he’s not entirely at home with dressing Even when he adds the finishing touch — his one pair of unbroken glasses. INT. JULIE’S LIVING-ROOM - NIGHT Eddie sits on a floral sofa next to Julie, watching TV. W all know how these things should go... Until we notice the TV is showing Evel Knievel at Wembley Stadium. He’s getting ready to jump 13 double-decker buse and Eddie can’t keep his eyes off it.
I did a jump like that when I was a kid. Thirteen milk crates.  17. She gets up and dims the lights.
It’s okay my parents aren’t back till 11. She sits back next to him. But Eddie remains glued to Eve Knievel barrelling towards the ramp.
You can sit closer if you want.
I can see alright from here.

I meant to me. Oh. Eddie turns to face her. They kiss but Eddie’s gaze is drawn back to the TV — Knie shooting into the air, suspended for an eternity... The image reflected in Eddie’s glasses until — CLICK. Jul hits the remote.
Come on. Concentrate.
But it’s no use. Eddie has had an idea. And it’s an idea that won’t go away as he trowels away on a low wall besid his Dad.
Guild requirement for pea-shingle is half an inch for the base. Eddie’s brain is miles away as he intently works the ceme into some kind of strange shape.
Are you listening?
I'm listening. Pea-shingle. Half an inch.
Then what the chuff is that?  18. The strange shape in Eddie’s plaster is revealed. A lovin sculpted ski-jump.
Eddie walks up the steps past the BOSA insignia.
In the reverent hush of the archive department, a BOSA OFFICIAL deals with Eddie’s inquiry.
I hate to disappoint you but we don't have an Olympic ski-jumping squad. He gives a consoling smile, but Eddie doesn’t look remote disappointed.
Not even a small one? The Official shakes his head.
Nope. Britain hasn’t had a ski- jumper since 1936.
Oh that’s terrible. He can barely contain himself.
He runs down the steps and launches himself off like a sk jumper. Down the street he goes, joyfully leaping off eve bench doing his best Ron Pickering impersonation.
Oh this is amazing, this is sensational.
Prince Andrew and Fergie’s newly happy faces are covered big dollop of mash potato. The fancy china is out for the Edwards’‘s Sunday roast.  19.
Which conversion are you talking about? The kitchen-dinette on the corner?

That’s the one. With the pebbledash. (he stabs a Brussel sprout) Bursting with possibilities. Eddie sits at the other end of the table, knee bouncing u and down like crazy. He repeatedly rolls a pea off his fo onto a mashed potato ski slope.
Mum. Dad. I’ve got an announcement. He can barely contain his excitement.
I’m not going to be taking my City and Guilds. I’ve made new plans. They turn and look.
Plans?
What plans? Eddie adjusts his glasses. Looks up with total conviction
I’m going to train as a ski-jumper and go to the Olympics.
Eddie rummages under the bed, packing up his ski gear. Janette watches aghast. Terry paces around in disbelief.
This is insane. You got your first exam in six weeks. Eddie just keeps packing.
It's not like I'm taking up ballet. It's still skiing. Only higher.  20.
How much higher?
Twenty stories. Her face drops with horror.
Give or take. He struggles to pull the zipper over his skis. No one off to help. Terry paces around in disbelief.
Britain doesn’t even have a ski- jumping squad.
It does now. He finally closes the zipper with a triumphant grin. Only see he is underestimated his father’s anger.
And how are you going to pay for all this? Because we’re not going through all that again with the bank and the bailiffs —
You won’t have to. Florian got me a job: junior ski instructor. Eddie picks up a ski resort brochure. Shows them a photo young kids being taught how to snowplow.
Florian?
From the Winter Centre. He’s back in Germany now. Eddie points to four ascending ski-jumps in the backgroun
In Garmisch. He leaves his parents blanching at the four ski-jumps — small, medium, large and gigantic.
He’s going to break his neck.  21.
I’m going to break his neck.
Eddie carries his gear downstairs, all ready to leave. Te follows but doesn’t help.
You can’t tell me you never had a dream when you were a kid.
Of course I did. I’m not made of stone, am I. This is news to Eddie. Great news.
Really? You never told me. He pauses at the bottom of the stairs. Turns to Terry.
«+. So what did you want to be?
A plasterer. They look at each other, both knowing it’s hopeless. Janette waits at the front door to see him off, as always
You're a stubborn bugger, you know that. Ever since you were a tot. Climbed out of every crib we put you in. She gives him a ferocious hug as if somehow this will sto him going.

The only baby in the world who liked landing on his head! Terry and Janette exchange a look - helpless and hit for Eighties pop music rises up as the brochure photo dissolv to the real ski-jumps all lit up with spotlights.  22.

A title card reads: “Garmisch, Germany. Site of the 1936 Winter Olympics.” Eddie sits up excitedly. Peers out of the van he’s hitche ride in. The music is coming from the Walkman he wears on his travels.

Eddie hurries into the floodlit landing arena, still carr his gear. The ascending row of ski-jump towers are lined above him. 15m. The 40m. The 70m and above them on its own hill, the jump. A huge iron monster. At the top, in silhouette, a JUMPER sets off down the ram Eddie moves closer as the Jumper shoots into the air, soa through the sparkling snowflakes, seemingly forever until lands and skids to a perfect stop. This is LARS MOBERG, the moustachioed superstar of the Swedish national squad. He rejoins a monastic huddle of ATHLETES and COACHES in yellow and blue jumpsuits. It is all very high-tech with video monitors and walkie- talkies. Eddie moves closer still and sees this isn’t just the national squad, it’s the Olympic squad. There it is, on all their gear like a lucky omen — the fi ring logo.
An LED alarm clock glows — 5.30am — in a tiny stuffy dormitory crammed with bunk-beds. Eddie creeps out with his gear, accidentally smacking a sleeping roommate with his ski-tip.
Hosenscheisser!
Bless you.  23.

Eddie bypasses the baby jump and goes straight to the 15m jump, all alone except for a distant snow groomer chuggin up the hill. He slots in his skis and sets off. Here it is, the moment truth... He shoots off the ramp and PLOPS onto the slope, gliding easily to a stop.
What a doddle. He can’t believe his luck. It’s so easy. He turns to look the next jump up — the 40m.

At the top of the ramp, Eddie finds this jump has two gro into which you slot your skis. He takes a breath and pushes off. This jump is significan faster. He shoots into the air, WHOOPING with delight. For one magical second he is flying, high above the twink resort below. Then reality returns and he CRASHES into the icy slope, sliding to a halt face first.
A row of YOUNG SKIERS shuffle into line for FLORIAN from front office.
Class, I want you to meet your new instructor, Mr. Eddie.
Good morning, Mr. Eddie. Eddie gives the kids a wave, acting all cool.
Eddie. Fast Eddie. Whatever you like.
Mr. Eddie’s going be teaching you the three S’s of skiing — smart, sensible, safe.  24. Eddie, we now see, has a huge bandage on his nose.
Practice their snowplows down the hill under Eddie’s supervision.

Okay, folks, nice practice postures. Now let's try it for real. Penguins to the left, polar bears to the right. Eddie’s concentration drifts enviously over to the Swedes the 70m. Flying through the air. Making it look so easy.
Room for one more?
Eddie emerges from a cloud of steam, sporting sturdy swim trunks and his huge nose plaster. Lars and the Swedish team begrudgingly shuffle up as Eddi plonks down on the bench.
Effermidaggen! Eddie Edwards, Great Britain. The Swedes just stare. Eddie presses on, undeterred.

I'll get right down to business if I may. I've just started on the 40m and I’m making solid progress, but I'd really appreciate a few tips. A vicious HISS of steam reveals the forbidding Swedish Co ladling water on the rocks. Like all Swedes everywhere, g half a chance, he has no clothes on.
You have been jumping long? Eddie looks everywhere but at the coach’s genitalia.
About a week.  25.

And you think you are ready to discover some advices from me? Eddie nods, sweat dotting his brow, this intensely nude m standing over him, hands on hips. SWEDISH COACH (CONT’D) You know who Matti Nykanen is?
He's only the best ski-jumper in the world. The Flying Finn.

The best and the most craziest. The Coach rocks back on his heels, arms akimbo. SWEDISH COACH (CONT’D) So maybe I give you something harder? It’s not exactly the phrase Eddie would choose, but okay. SWEDISH COACH (CONT’D) What is the maximum wideness for a jumping ski? Eddie boldly holds out his thumb and forefinger. SWEDISH COACH (CONT’D) And that is what exactly? Eddie can't help it. His gaze drops for a millisecond.
++. About four inches. The Coach SNAPS his fingers at Lars.
The maximum wideness is 11.5 cm.
That is about four inches, isn’t it.
Not “exactly,” no. So you tell me what is the most length of the ski?  26.
"The most length of the ski?" (why doesn't anyone else find this funny?) Eight foot two. It’s another bold guess and it provokes another finger-sn at another naked jumper.
The ski has permission to be 77.5 cm taller than the height of the jumper, but with no more taller than 275 cm. Eddie hitches his trunks nervously.
Well, like I said, I’m just starting out.

In Sweden, the time to be starting out is when you are five. This time he gives a double finger-snap and the whole tea leaps up. SWEDISH COACH (CONT’D) We have not the moments for beginners. Good day. Out he goes, his naked team obediently shuffling after hi
Two skis plop over a fence. Followed by Eddie, all alone except for the distant snowgrooming machine on the hillsi

Bloody Swedes. What’d they ever do apart from invent the meatball? Eddie sets off down the 40m jump and it’s the same result another ice-gouging wipe-out. Eddie lies splayed on the ice, groaning in pain. He tries move, but it’s agony. The SOUND of the snowgrooming machine gets nearer until i crests the hill, headlights blazing, and comes to a stop right next to Eddie’s splayed form.  27. The shadowy figure of the DRIVER drops to the ground and inspects one of Eddie’s craters. All Eddie can see is a glowing red tiparillo tip.

So you’re the mystery elf who’s been hacking up my slope every night. He walks over, dramatically backlit by his headlights, an peers down at Eddie. AMERICAN VOICE (CONT’D) It’s just you? No pick-axe? This is BRONSON PEARY, the resort’s resident snow groomer He’s commanding in a weathered sort of way with a certain hard-partying ski bum panache — and yet he’s still only a maintenance man.
You do realize the time to start jumping is when you’re five or six.
Thanks. The Swedes already told me that. Eddie gets as far as his hands and knees, wincing in pain
Did they also mention you've got the wrong body shape? Eddie has to check. Yes, this is the cigarillo-puffing snowgroomer telling him this.
Just stating the obvious.
Well, state this. He flicks him a V-sign. Peary climbs back behind the whee and gives a raspy laugh.
And one more thing. You got the wrong skis.
Oh, and one more thing. There’s no such thing as British ski-jumpers. They don’t exist.  28. Eddie finally snaps.
What’d you know about it anyway? Peary’s face darkens - some strange wounded flicker of reflection. He turns and climbs back behind the wheel.
Don’t even think about going on the 70.
You can’t stop me. I’m an employee.
Still need my permission for the 70. He steers his rusty snow machine back up the hill, spluttering into the mist. Eddie watches it go, thoroughly bemused.
You'd never guess he was part of the US Olympic Squad.
Eddie points out the window towards the slope.
Who, that guy?
It’s true. Bronson Peary. He was in the ‘72 squad under Warren Sharp. Eddie’s jaw drops. No way.
“Bronson Peary...?” How come I never heard of him?
Well, they kicked him out, obviously. Just before the Games.
What for?  29.
Boozing. Womanizing. Being an impossible asshole... Take your pick. Eddie doesn’t care. He’s already smitten. looks back outside at the snowgroomer struggling up the h
No kidding. Warren Sharp, ‘72... INT. PEARY’S WORKSHOP - DAY Peary’s weatherbeaten profile — face up as he works underneath the snowgroomer.
No.
Come on. All I want is a few tips. Eddie crouches down, trying to make eye contact.
Florian told me how you used to jump in America.
Yeah, well, Florian also said he screwed Princess Stephanie of Monaco.
He showed me a clipping with a photo.
She's just a lookalike. He met her in Verbier on a stag night.
Of you. The 90 meter at Lake Placid — 1969, American Youth Cup finals. You clocked 118 meters! Peary slides out and climbs into his cabin.
Four years with Warren Sharp!
Three years.  30. Eddie doesn’t care. It’s still amazing.
You shouldn’t be fixing rust buckets, you should be coaching. “Rust bucket”? Peary’s face darkens.
This is a PB 200 with a multiflex tiller. Grooms 81 square meters an hour. It also leaks gunk. Peary surreptitiously wipes his hand he coaxes the engine into life.
I’m just saying if I had your pedigree and experience —
Well, you don’t. He lurches out of the garage, Eddie giving chase.
